bad.work: The Gambols of Ghosts According with Their Affections Previous to the Final Judgment

title.reg: The Gambols of Ghosts According with Their Affections Previous to the Final Judgment

titlestmt.title: The Gambols of Ghosts According with Their Affections Previous to the Final Judgment : electronic edition
titlestmt.principal: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
titlestmt.sponsor: The Library of Congress, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and the University of Rochester

filedesc.extent: 1 XML file approx. 85KB; 2 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 53KB to 778KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; UNC LibrariesMay 2014
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of fully searchable and scalable electronic editions of the following works related to Blake’s development of his illustrations to Robert Blair’s The Grave: Preliminary Sketches for Robert Blair’s The Grave, listed under Drawings and Paintings, Pencil Sketches; Preliminary Drawings for Robert Blair’s The Grave, listed under Drawings and Paintings, Monochrome Wash Drawings; and Preliminary Illustrations to Robert Blair’s The Grave, listed under Drawings and Paintings, Water Color Drawings.
In addition, we are republishing the following works, previously presented in our Preview mode, to make their designs fully searchable: Robert Blair, The Grave, the 1808 book listed under Commercial Book Illustrations, Designed by Blake and Engraved by Other Engravers; Deaths Door, listed under Separate Plates and Plates in Series, Designed and Engraved by Blake; and Illustrations to Robert Blair’s The Grave, the series of twenty finished designs, listed under Drawings and Paintings, Water Color Drawings.
Taken together, these works in a variety of media present a comprehensive overview of one of Blake’s major projects as an illustrator and exemplify his working methods as he developed rough sketches into finished water colors. The evolution of any one design can be traced via links presented under Related Works in the Archive on the pull-down menus, lower left on the main viewing page for each work.
In October 1805, Blake was commissioned by the engraver and would-be publisher Robert H. Cromek to prepare forty drawings illustrating Robert Blair's The Grave, a popular "Graveyard" school poem first published in 1743. Cromek originally planned to select twenty of these designs for a deluxe edition of the poem. Blake launched into the project with great enthusiasm, rapidly sketching out his illustrations in pencil, developing some into wash drawings, and then producing a group of more finished water colors for presentation to Cromek. In a first prospectus of November 1805, Cromek names Blake as both the designer and engraver of fifteen designs. Blake etched one image, Deaths Door, in white-line, but Cromek rejected it. The dark power of the print appeals to modern tastes, but was far from fashionable in the early nineteenth century. In a second prospectus, also of November 1805, Cromek announced that Louis Schiavonetti would engrave twelve designs for the new edition. Blake had lost the potentially lucrative commission to engrave his own designs; his relationship with Cromek descended into anger and argument. In spite of their disagreement, Cromek included a portrait of Blake as a frontispiece to the volume, published in 1808. Cromek promoted the book aggressively and the illustrations to The Grave became Blake's best known work through much of the nineteenth century.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

changestmt.respstmt: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill Technical Editor: Michael FoxProject Manager: Joseph FletcherProject Coordinator, University of Rochester: Laura BellConsultant on Special Projects: Ashley ReedBibliographer:Mark CrosbyProject Assistants: Esther Arnold,Amber Bertin,Abby Brengle,Katherine Calvin,Adam Engel,Andrea Everett,Duncan Graham,Shannon Jaime,Gabrielle Kiriloff,Eric Loy,Kate Massie,Adam McCune,Ali McGhee,Anastasia Nikolis,Kylie Regan,Adair Rispoli,Hardeep Sidhu,Margaret Speer,Sarah Tolf,Danny Tsegai,Lisa Vandenbossche,Nikolaus Wasmoen,Alia Wegner,Megan Wilson

objtitle.title: *The Gambols of Ghosts According with Their Affections Previous to the Final Judgment*

objinfo.medium: pencil with touches of brown wash
objinfo.watermark: IHS IxVILLEDARYThere is a small cross just above the H.

provenance.name: Yale Center for British Art
provenance.note: Probably inherited by Blake's wife Catherine upon his death in 1827; probably acquired by Frederick Tatham upon Catherine Blake's death in 1831; probably one of the works sold anonymously, Sotheby's, 29 April 1862, in lot 165 with three other works (13s. to the dealer Henry Palser) or in lot 167 with three other works (11s. to the dealer Henry Palser); Alfred Aspland by 1876, sold from his collection Sotheby's, 27 June 1885, lot 65 (10s. to the dealer Ogden, Oxford); later in the collection of Herbert Thompson according to an inscription by Archibald G. B. Russell in his copy of the 1876 Burlington Fine Arts Club exhibition catalogue of works by Blake; later in the collection of Mrs. Charles Hill; her heirs no later than 1977; sold through the dealer Somerville and Simpson in 1977 to Paul Mellon; given by Mellon to the Yale Center for British Art in 1977 or early 1978.

desc.objtitle: The Gambols of Ghosts According with Their Affections Previous to the Final Judgment, Object 1 (Butlin 636)

objnote.p: The drawing is inscribed "Blake," lower right, not in Blake's hand. The verso is inscribed ""From the Grave," "Gilchrist 72 page 247," and "Aspland coll 65 (74)."

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in a graveyard that stretches across the lower portion of the design. Two gravestones appear in the lower left corner and at least one tomb stands in the lower right corner. A Gothic church stands at the left border of the design. The roof come to a sharp point, topped with a double cross. A single visible stair or step appears below the door. All figures in the scene may be ghosts. At least nine figures stand or walk in a procession to the right of the church. The leftmost figure stands in the doorway of the church and is seen from behind. He or she may hold a lit candle. A gowned male, partly bald and bending forward, stands second from the left. His right leg is bent as he ascends the step at the base of the church. A pair of gowned figures (possibly children) stand third and fourth from the left. The child to the left faces left and holds a lit candle. His or her left leg is extending backward, suggesting that he or she is striding forward. The child to the right, possibly also holding a lit candle, is seen from behind and faces left. A pair of gowned males with long hair stand fifth and sixth from the left. The figure to the left is apparently in mid-stride with one leg bent forward. His left arm is bent and he holds an open book. His eyes are down; he may be reading. The head of the sixth figure from the left is turned to the left; he may be looking at his companion. The figure seventh from the left holds a plate or tray carrying loaves of bread or other food. Only the upper body of the figure eighth from the left is visible. The figure is seen partly from behind and faces left. The figure ninth from the left is only visible from the shoulders up, facing left or away. A leafy tree with distinct branches stands in the center of the design. The full moon appears in the night sky to the left of the tree. Six figures run or dance to the left and right of the tree in the center of the design; they may represent ghosts. The figure farthest left is seen from behind and bends or arches to the right. Second from the left, a nude male(?) is seen from behind. He strides to the left with his left leg bent and right leg extended back to the right. The figure's arms are raised nearly horizontally with the palms held vertically and out away from his body. The figure third from the left strides to the right with his or her right leg bent. A nude male appears fourth from the left. He runs to the left with his left leg extended backward nearly horizontally. Both arms are held horizontally, palms vertical. A nude figure appears fifth from the left. The figure runs forward and to the left with his or her arms crossed and right leg extended backward and left foot on tiptoe. His or her head is down. A sketchy figure that may face right stands farthest right. Twenty-five figures appear near the borders or corners of the design. The upper bodies of two nude figures appear in the lower left portion of the design; the figures are partially buried in the earth. The figure to the left may be female. She faces right with her head bent back. Her arms are bent upward, with her hands curled into fists. The figure to the right is male and has short hair. He faces forward with his head turned to the left; his mouth is open and he may look toward the figure to the left. The figure's arms are bent upward with his hands curled into fists. Two figures lie on the ground at the lower border of the design. The lower figure, likely male and nude, lies horizontally, facing away. His arms are raised vertically relative to his body and may be grasping the tombstone to the left. His right leg is bent and drawn up and his left leg is extended up and to the right; another ghost holds and likely pulls him by the ankle. The lower figure may be a nude female with long hair, lying supine. Her right arm is at her side and may be grasping at the leg of the figure above and to the right of her. She may be pulling the ghost to her right. A nude, bald male hovers or flies in the lower right portion of the design. Both arms are extended down and to the left; he grasps and may pull the ankle of the ghost below with both hands. His mouth is open (he may be howling) and he looks up and to the left, though his body faces right. An open book rests on the ground to the right of a tombstone along the lower border of the design. A bishop's crozier (a staff with a coiled terminal) appears to the right. A nude male(?) figure sits, facing left, on a tomb in the lower right corner of the design. He is hunched forward slightly. His left leg is bent and raised slightly, as though in the process of stomping. A nude, bald male crouches on a tomb in the lower right corner of the design. Both arms are down and he holds and pulls the hair of the buried figure below. He faces forward and looks down and to the left, with his left foot on tiptoe. The figure below is visible from the eyes up. Three heads in the lower right corner of the design, visible from the shoulders up, face forward and look up, with mouths open, perhaps howling. In the lower right portion of the design two nude figures recline. The left figure of the pair faces forward, legs extended to the left. Its left arm is at its side, but bent as though bracing its body on the left elbow. Its right arm is raised vertically and bent over its head. It may hold a stick or axe in its right hand. The rightmost reclining figure faces away, legs extended to the left. Its right arm may be at its side. A gowned figure hovers along the right margin of the design, facing right and down. Its right arm is extended vertically relative to its body, as though reaching downward. To the right of the figures dancing around the tree hover three nude figures. The bottommost figure of the group is upside down, facing slightly left with his(?) head bent back and mouth open. His legs are bent, as though braced. His arms are reaching downward, relative to his body, holding onto the head of the figure above him. The middle figure of the group is supine, upside down. His(?) arms are raised above his head and his legs are extended up slightly. The topmost figure of the group faces forward with its legs extended down; with both arms, he holds onto the feet or legs of the figure below him. To the right of the tree branches hover three figures. The leftmost and rightmost figures appear to be children, facing forward and perhaps gowned. The central figure may be gowned and faces forward, looking slightly down to the left; with both hands, he or she holds onto the children on either side. A group of at least six figures hovers or flies above the tree in the center of the design. The leftmost figure of this group faces left and hunches forward slightly, legs bent and drawn up. The middle three figures face right and may be gowned. The figure second from the right may face right and up, legs extended backward and to the right. The rightmost figure may be sitting, facing forward. Its legs may be bent but extended to the right. Some clouds may be visible in the sky among the group of figures hovering across the top of the design. Two figures hover or fly in front of the church spire. The uppermost figure's body is horizontal, facing left and down. Its legs are bent slightly and extended backward. Its arms may be at its side. The figure on the bottom of the pair faces forward and slightly left. Its legs are bent and extended backward, with its left arm raised horizontally and its right arm bent upward over its head. It may be gowned and may hold something in each hand.

component.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in a graveyard that stretches across the lower portion of the design. Two gravestones appear in the lower left corner and at least one tomb stands in the lower right corner.

A Gothic church stands at the left border of the design. The roof come to a sharp point, topped with a double cross. The front of the church may be a large open door. A single visible stair or step appears below the door.

At least nine figures stand or walk in a procession to the right of the church. The leftmost figure stands in the doorway of the church and is seen from behind, facing left. He or she may hold a lit candle.

At least nine figures stand or walk in a procession to the right of the church. A gowned male, partly bald and bending forward, stands second from the left. His right leg is bent as he ascends the step at the base of the church. His arms are at his side, but bent backward with his hands perhaps clasped behind his back.

At least nine figures stand or walk in a procession to the right of the church. A pair of gowned figures (possibly children) stand third and fourth from the left. The child to the left faces left and away slightly, holding a lit candle. His or her left leg is extending backward, suggesting that he or she is striding forward.

At least nine figures stand or walk in a procession to the right of the church. A pair of gowned figures (possibly children) stand third and fourth from the left. The child to the right, possibly also holding a lit candle, is seen from behind and faces left, visible only as a head.

At least nine figures stand or walk in a procession to the right of the church. A pair of gowned males with long hair stand fifth and sixth from the left. The figure to the left is apparently in mid-stride with one leg bent forward. His left arm is bent and he holds an open book. His eyes are down; he may be reading. He bends forward slightly as he looks at his book, facing left and slightly away. The head of the sixth figure from the left is turned to the left; he may be looking at his companion.

At least nine figures stand or walk in a procession to the right of the church. A pair of gowned males with long hair stand fifth and sixth from the left. The figure to the right faces left and away but looks to the figure to the left. His shoulders are slightly hunched forward.

At least nine figures stand or walk in a procession to the right of the church. The figure seventh from the left holds a plate or tray carrying loaves of bread or other food. It may be a gowned male with short hair, who kneels on bended right knee. Alternately, he may look down and be walking forward. His left arm is at his side but bent.

At least nine figures stand or walk in a procession to the right of the church. Only the upper body of the figure eighth from the left is visible. The figure is seen partly from behind and faces left, bending forward slightly. Like the figure to the left, it might be kneeling or walking.
At least nine figures stand or walk in a procession to the right of the church. The figure ninth from the left is only visible from the shoulders up, facing left or away.
One or two lit candles appear among the procession of eleven figures. The bearers of these candles are not visible or immediately apparent.
A leafy tree with distinct branches stands in the center of the design.
The full moon appears in the night sky to the left of the tree.
Six figures run or dance to the left and right of the tree in the center of the design; they may represent ghosts. The figure farthest left is seen from behind and bends or arches to the right.

Six figures run or dance to the left and right of the tree in the center of the design; they may represent ghosts. Second from the left, a nude male(?) is seen from behind. He strides to the left with his left leg bent and on tiptoe, and his right leg extended back to the right. The figure's arms are raised nearly horizontally with the palms held vertically and out away from his body. This figure may have long hair that streams to the right and may trail a long piece of cloth from his or her right foot, although his or her body appears nude. The body is twisted so that the lower half faces left and the upper half faces right; he or she may be looking at the figure to the right.

Six figures run or dance to the left and right of the tree in the center of the design; they may represent ghosts. The figure third from the left strides to the right with his or her right leg bent and on tiptoe, left leg exended backward. This figure faces forward, mouth open, and may reach toward the figure to the left.

Six figures run or dance to the left and right of the tree in the center of the design; they may represent ghosts. A nude male appears fourth from the left. He runs to the left with his left leg extended backward nearly horizontally. His right leg is bent, but not visible below the knee. Both arms are held horizontally, palms vertical. He may have short hair.

Six figures run or dance to the left and right of the tree in the center of the design; they may represent ghosts. A nude figure appears fifth from the left. The figure runs forward and to the left with his or her arms crossed and right leg extended backward and left foot on tiptoe. His or her head is down.
Six figures run or dance to the left and right of the tree in the center of the design; they may represent ghosts. A sketchy figure that may face right stands farthest right.

The upper bodies of two nude figures appear in the lower left portion of the design; the figures are partially buried in the earth. The figure to the left may be female. She faces right with her head bent back. Her arms are bent upward, with her hands curled into fists.

The upper bodies of two nude figures appear in the lower left portion of the design; the figures are partially buried in the earth. The figure to the right is male and has short hair. He faces forward with his head turned to the left; his mouth is open and he may look toward the figure to the left. The figure's arms are bent upward with his hands curled into fists.

Two figures lie on the ground at the lower border of the design. The lower figure is nude, likely male, and lies horizontally, facing away. His arms are raised vertically relative to his body and may be grasping the tombstone to the left. His right leg is bent and drawn up and his left leg is extended up and to the right; another ghost holds and likely pulls him by the ankle.

Two figures lie on the ground at the lower border of the design. The upper figure may be a nude female with long hair, lying supine. Her right arm is at her side and may be grasping at the leg of the figure above and to the right of her. She may be pulling on the ghost to her right.

A nude, bald male hovers or flies in the lower right portion of the design. Both arms are extended down and to the left; he grasps and may pull the ankle of the ghost below with both hands. His mouth is open (he may be howling) and he looks up and to the left, though his body faces right. His right leg is extended down and to the left.
An open book rests on the ground to the right of a tombstone along the lower border of the design. A bishop's crozier (a staff with a coiled terminal) appears to the right.

A nude male(?) figure sits, facing left, on a tomb in the lower right corner of the design. He is hunched forward slightly, with his visible left arm braced on his seat. His left leg is bent and raised slightly, as though in the process of stomping. His mouth may be open and he may be frowning.

A nude, bald male crouches on a tomb in the lower right corner of the design. Both arms are down and he holds and pulls the hair of the buried figure below. He faces forward and looks down and to the left, with his left foot on tiptoe.
The head of a buried figure, visible from the eyes up, appears in the lower right corner of the design. The figure's long hair is pulled upwards by the figure above.

In the lower right portion of the design two nude figures recline. The left figure of the pair faces forward, legs extended to the left. Its left arm is at its side, but bent as though bracing its body on the left elbow. Its right arm is raised vertically and bent over its head. It may hold a stick or axe in its right hand. It may be sitting on a tomb or hovering in the air. The shape of its upper body suggests that it may be female.

In the lower right portion of the design two nude figures recline. The rightmost reclining figure faces away, legs extended to the left. Its right arm may be at its side. It may be sitting on a tomb or hovering in the air.
A gowned figure hovers along the right margin of the design, facing right and down. Its right arm is extended vertically relative to its body, as though reaching downward.

To the right of the figures dancing around the tree hover three nude figures. The bottommost figure of the group is upside down, facing slightly left with his(?) head bent back and mouth open. His legs are bent, as though braced. His arms are reaching downward, relative to his body, holding or pulling the head of the figure above him.

To the right of the figures dancing around the tree hover three nude figures. The middle figure of the group is supine, upside down. His(?) arms are raised above his head and may be pushing against the figure below him. His legs are extended up slightly.

To the right of the figures dancing around the tree hover three nude figures. The topmost figure of the group faces forward with its legs extended down; with both arms, he holds onto the feet or legs of the figure below him and may be pulling.

To the right of the tree branches hover three figures. The leftmost and rightmost figures appear to be children, facing forward and perhaps gowned. The leftmost figure holds its arms bent up, with its right leg perhaps extended backward to suggest walking. The rightmost figure bends its legs sightly and has its right arm at its side. Both children are holding a hand of the figure in the center, which may be their mother.

To the right of the tree branches hover three figures. The central figure may be gowned and faces forward, looking slightly down to the left; with both hands, he or she holds onto the children on either side. She(?) may be the mother of the two children.

A group of at least six figures hovers or flies above the tree in the center of the design. The leftmost figure of this group faces left and hunches forward slightly, legs bent and drawn up. It looks down and may be squatting or sitting.

A group of at least six figures hovers or flies above the tree in the center of the design. The middle three figures' bodies face left but their heads are turned to look right. All these figures may be gowned. The leftmost two figures of this group bend their legs as though walking, while the rightmost leans to the left, legs extended backward.

A group of at least six figures hovers or flies above the tree in the center of the design. The figure second from the right may face right and up, legs extended backward and to the right. It may be resting on a cloud.

A group of at least six figures hovers or flies above the tree in the center of the design. The rightmost figure may be sitting on a cloud, facing forward and looking down. Its legs may be bent but extended to the right.
Some clouds may be visible in the sky among the group of figures hovering across the top of the design.
Two figures hover or fly in front of the church spire. The uppermost figure's body is horizontal, facing left and down. Its legs are bent slightly and extended backward. Its arms may be at its side.

Two figures hover or fly in front of the church spire. The figure on the bottom of the pair faces forward and slightly left. Its legs are bent and extended backward, with its left arm raised horizontally and its right arm bent upward over its head. It may be gowned and hold something in each hand.
